articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Went to Canada, and a Dream of ‘Medicare for All’ Flourished
articles.snippet: The Vermont senator has staked his presidential campaign, and much of his political legacy, on transforming health care in America. His mother’s illness, and a trip he made to study the Canadian system, help explain why.
articles.abstract: The Vermont senator has staked his presidential campaign, and much of his political legacy, on transforming health care in America. His mother’s illness, and a trip he made to study the Canadian system, help explain why.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — In July 1987, Bernie Sanders, then the mayor of Burlington, Vt., arrived in Ottawa convinced he was about to see the future of health care.

articles.headline: For Boris Johnson, Another Bad Day and Another Big Defeat in Parliament
articles.snippet: Monday was supposed to be a day of triumph for Britain’s new prime minister. Instead, he lost his bid for a new election on the same day a law went into effect barring a no-deal Brexit.
articles.abstract: Monday was supposed to be a day of triumph for Britain’s new prime minister. Instead, he lost his bid for a new election on the same day a law went into effect barring a no-deal Brexit.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — British lawmakers, capping what may be one of the most abysmal starts any British leader has ever endured, on Monday rejected Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s bid to hold a new national election.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Informant Extracted From Russia Had Sent Secrets to U.S. for Decades
articles.snippet: American intelligence officials had previously tried to extract the source from Russia in 2016, but the informant had initially refused.
articles.abstract: American intelligence officials had previously tried to extract the source from Russia in 2016, but the informant had initially refused.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Decades ago, the C.I.A. recruited and carefully cultivated a midlevel Russian official who began rapidly advancing through the governmental ranks. Eventually, American spies struck gold: The longtime source landed an influential position that came with access to the highest level of the Kremlin.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Retailers Walk Thin Line by Asking, Not Telling, Shoppers Not to Carry Guns
articles.snippet: Gun-control groups praised Walmart and others for discouraging customers in so-called open carry states from bringing firearms to stores, while gun-rights groups seem unworried.
articles.abstract: Gun-control groups praised Walmart and others for discouraging customers in so-called open carry states from bringing firearms to stores, while gun-rights groups seem unworried.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Amad, a gun rights activist and the vice president of Open Carry Texas, is not especially bothered by Walmart’s recent announcement that it is “respectfully requesting” that customers not openly carry guns into its stores.

articles.headline: California Labor Bill, Near Passage, Is Blow to Uber and Lyft
articles.snippet: The companies seem to have fallen short in efforts to dodge legislation classifying many workers in the gig economy as employees and not contractors.
articles.abstract: The companies seem to have fallen short in efforts to dodge legislation classifying many workers in the gig economy as employees and not contractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — A pack of Teamsters fanned out through California’s Capitol building last week, marching into legislators’ offices and pressing them to pass a bill that would force Uber and Lyft to treat their drivers as employees. The measure, Assembly Bill 5, would entitle gig workers to protections like a minimum wage and unemployment benefits. “Yes on A.B. 5! Yes on A.B. 5!” they chorused.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: ‘This Is the Most Lonesome Job’: Ride With a ‘Hot Shot’ Oilfield Trucker in Texas
articles.snippet: As the United States has become the world’s largest producer of oil, demand in the fields has soared for pipes or drums in a hurry. That’s where Mike Wilkinson fits in.
articles.abstract: As the United States has become the world’s largest producer of oil, demand in the fields has soared for pipes or drums in a hurry. That’s where Mike Wilkinson fits in.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the United States has become the world’s largest producer of oil, demand in the fields has soared for pipes or drums in a hurry. That’s where Mike Wilkinson fits in.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Tamir Kalifa

articles.headline: China’s Pork Prices Soar, Adding to Beijing’s Troubles
articles.snippet: Chinese grocery bills were already rising because of the trade war. Officials are now calling for “an attitude of urgency.”
articles.abstract: Chinese grocery bills were already rising because of the trade war. Officials are now calling for “an attitude of urgency.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Things that keep China’s top leaders up at night: a stalling economy, a bruising trade war and, increasingly, pigs.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: Dan Bishop, North Carolina Republican, Wins Special Election
articles.snippet: Mr. Bishop’s narrow victory over Dan McCready in a conservative district demonstrated warning signs for President Trump in 2020.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bishop’s narrow victory over Dan McCready in a conservative district demonstrated warning signs for President Trump in 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Dan Bishop, a Republican state senator, scored a narrow victory on Tuesday in a special House election in North Carolina that demonstrated President Trump’s appeal with his political base but also highlighted his party’s deepening unpopularity with suburban voters.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Share of Americans With Health Insurance Declined in 2018
articles.snippet: The drop, despite a strong economy, was the first since 2009 and at least partly caused by efforts to weaken the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: The drop, despite a strong economy, was the first since 2009 and at least partly caused by efforts to weaken the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fewer Americans are living in poverty, but for the first time in years, more of them lack health insurance.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Margot Sanger-Katz and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Netanyahu, Facing Tough Israel Election, Pledges to Annex a Third of West Bank
articles.snippet: The move by Israel’s prime minister, who faces an election in a week, would reduce any future Palestinian state to an enclave encircled by Israel.
articles.abstract: The move by Israel’s prime minister, who faces an election in a week, would reduce any future Palestinian state to an enclave encircled by Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Tuesday that he would move swiftly to annex nearly a third of the occupied West Bank if voters returned him to power in the election next week, seizing what he called a historic opportunity from a sympathetic White House to give Israel “secure, permanent borders.”
